modules.description: Provides operations to extract a score as a float and a label as a boolean from instances of type t. Works with a structured data type t that encapsulates numeric and boolean attributes. Used to process classification results where numerical confidence and binary outcomes are required.

Provides functions to extract a numeric score and a boolean label from instances of type t. Works with structured data representing classification results or predictions. Used to process and evaluate model outputs in machine learning workflows.

Provides list abstractions with custom comparison and equality logic, overriding standard List functions. Supports operations on lists using element-based checks for equality and ordering. Examples include comparing lists for structural equivalence and checking list membership with custom rules. Designed for consistent behavior in list manipulations across different contexts.

Maintains a collection of elements ranked by score, allowing insertion of new elements based on their score and retrieving the top-ranked entries. It operates on a type 'a t, storing elements along with their associated floating-point scores. Used to track the highest-scoring items in applications like leaderboards or priority queues with fixed capacity.

is a collection of utility functions and data structures designed to support common programming tasks. It includes types such as lists, options, and results, along with operations like mapping, filtering, and folding. Users can perform transformations on data, handle optional values, and manage error states effectively. Examples include converting lists to strings, safely accessing elements, and combining results from multiple operations.

Calculates precision, recall, F1 score, and mean squared error using arrays of predicted and actual values. Operates on float and int arrays to evaluate model performance in machine learning tasks. Enables direct comparison between binary classification results and regression predictions.

combines utilities for processing classification data, list manipulation with custom logic, ranked element storage, and general-purpose data transformations. It includes types for scores, labels, ranked collections, and standard functional abstractions like lists and options. Users can extract model outputs, compare lists structurally, manage priority queues, and handle optional or error-prone computations. For example, it enables evaluating prediction accuracy, checking list membership with custom rules, maintaining top-scoring entries, and safely processing incomplete data.
